gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: GT10-11 - Particulate Th and Pa from the U.S. GEOTRACES NAT project of the U.S. GEOTRACES program

gmd:abstract.gco:CharacterString: Depth profiles of seawater suspended dissolved and particulate 232Th, 230Th, and 231Pa Dataset Description: <p><strong>DMO NOTE on GNAZT Suspended Particulate Th/Pa:</strong><br />- version 4 served on 29 Sept 2015; combined both dissolved and particulate Th &amp; Pa datasets into one.<br /><strong><span style="background-color:#FFA07A">See dataset "</span><a href="http://www.bco-dmo.org/dataset/3847"><span style="background-color:#FFA07A">GT10-11 - Dissolved and Particulate Th and Pa</span></a><span style="background-color:#FFA07A">"</span></strong><br />- version 3: none<br />- version 2: 8 Aug. 2014<br />- version 1: 31 Jan. 2013</p><p><strong>Notes:</strong></p><p>This data refers to the "suspended" size fraction of seawater particles (written with the suffix "_susp"). The particulate samples were collected by in-situ pumping over paired 0.8?m Pall Supor800 polyethersulfone filters behind a 51 ?m Sefar polyester mesh prefilter (See sampling Methodology below for details). Analysis of the paired Supor filters represents a particle size class approximating 0.45-51 µm (Bishop et al. 2012), while the top filter alone represents 0.8-51 µm and it is this size class referred to here as "suspended". We measured a select number of top and bottom filters separately for radionuclides and found that the bottom filters had radionuclide levels that were indistinguishable from clean filter process blanks. Therefore whether or not samples were analyzed as top and bottom paired, or the top filter alone, we refer to the particle size class represented as 0.8-51 µm.</p><p>Radionuclide concentrations are given as the mass of radionuclide contained in a given volume of pumped seawater: femtograms (fg = 10-15 g) radionuclide per kilogram (kg) seawater for 230Th and 231Pa, and picograms (pg = 10-12 g) radionuclide per kg seawater for 232Th. Sample size was measured by volume (liters) of seawater pumped by mass flow controllers on the in-situ pumps, but we converted seawater volume to seawater mass using a fixed seawater density of 1.025 kg/L. The units are written simply as fg/kg and pg/kg. Note that the counterpart radionuclide data in the dissolved phase (&lt;0.45 µm) from this CRUISE are also reported in fg and pg per kilogram of seawater. Concentrations below detection are listed as ‘bdl’.</p> Acquisition Description: <p><strong>Sampling and Analytical Methodology: &nbsp;<br />1. Sampling:</strong><br />Size-fractionated particles were collected using McLane Research in-situ pumps (WTS-LV) that had been modified to accommodate two flowpaths (Lam and Morris Patent pending). &nbsp; The wire-out was used to target depths during deployment, and a self-recording Seabird 19plus CTD deployed at the end of the line and RBR data loggers attached to three of the eight pumps were used to correct for actual depths during pumping.</p><p>Filter holders used were 142 mm-diameter "mini-MULVFS" style filter holders with two stages for two size fractions and multiple baffle systems designed to ensure even particle distribution and prevent particle loss (Bishop et al. 2012). &nbsp;One of two filter holder/flowpaths was loaded with a 51µm Sefar polyester mesh prefilter followed by paired 0.8 µm Pall Supor800 polyethersulfone filters. &nbsp;Each cast also had "dipped blank" filters deployed. &nbsp;These were the full filters sets (prefilter followed by paired Supor filters) sandwiched within a 1 µm polyester mesh filter, loaded into perforated polypropylene containers, attached with plastic cable ties to a pump frame, and deployed. &nbsp;Dipped blank filters were exposed to seawater for the length of the deployment and processed and analyzed as regular samples, and thus functioned as full seawater process blanks. &nbsp;We analyzed half portions of the top and bottom filters from the "dipped" blank from 1 or more depths for 7 stations.</p><p>All filters and filter holders were acid leached prior to use according to methods recommended in the GEOTRACES sample and sample-handing Protocols (Geotraces 2010).</p><p><strong>2. Analysis:</strong><br />The Supor filters were subsampled in an on-shore laboratory at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and shipped to the participating labs for Pa/Th analysis. Twenty-five to 50% of the paired Supor filters, representing 55-350 L of seawater, were used for Pa/Th analysis. Analyses were similar but differed slightly for the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, WHOI and the University of Minnesota. Details of each groups methodologies can be found in reports by Anderson et al. (2012), Auro et al. (2012) and Shen et al. (2002, 2003, 2012), respectively. Below we give a typical procedure used at L-DEO for illustrative purposes.<br />&nbsp;<br /><strong>2.1 L-DEO procedures</strong><br />&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />Filters were folded into 60 mL Teflon jars and weighed aliquots of the artificial isotope yield monitors 229Th (1 pg) and 233Pa (0.3-0.4 pg) and 7-8 mg dissolved Fe were added to each sample. Filters were first heated in ~5 mL 8 N HNO3 for 1-2 hours at 150°C, then 4-5 mL HClO4 was added and heat was increased to 200°C until dense white fumes appeared for ~10-20 min. The heat was then reduced to 180°C and the samples were covered with a Teflon watch cover. After 1-4 hrs, oxidation of the Supor material accelerated, sometimes producing a foam. A foamed sample would be allowed to cool, and re-heated after the beaker walls and watch cover were washed with small amounts of HNO3 or Milli-Q water. When the Supor material was largely broken down, the watch covers were removed and HF was added in 2 aliquots of ~10-15 drops in between reheating until attaining dense HClO4 fumes for at least 10 min.</p><p>After total dissolution of the sample, the sample-HClO4 residue was taken up in dilute HCl, and transferred to 50 mL centrifuge tubes with water rinses. Ten to 20 drops of NH4OH were added to raise pH to 8-8.5 when iron (oxy)hydroxide precipitated. This precipitate was then centrifuged, decanted, washed with Milli-Q H2O, centrifuged, and dissolved in 12 M HCl for a series of anion-exchange chromatography using 6 mL polypropylene columns each containing a 1 mL bed of Bio-rad resin (AG1-X8, 100-200 mesh size) and a 45 µm porous polyethylene frit (Anderson et al. 2012). The final column elutions were dried down at 180°C in the presence of 2 drops of HClO4 and taken up in approximately 1 mL of 0.16 M HNO3/0.026 M HF for mass spectrometric analysis. All acids and bases used were Fisher Chemical OPTIMA grade.&nbsp;<br />&nbsp;<br />Concentrations of 232Th, 230Th and 231Pa were calculated by isotope dilution using nuclide ratios determined on a Thermo Scientific Element XR Inductively-couple plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) in low resolution. All measurements were done using a peak jumping routine in ion counting mode. A solution of SRM129, a natural U standard, was run to determine the mass bias correction (assuming that the mass fractionation for Th and Pa are the same as for U). Each sample measurement was bracketed by measurement of an aliquot of the run solution, used to correct for the instrument background count rates on the masses measured. To correct for potential tailing of 232Th into the minor Th and Pa isotopes, beam intensities were measured at the half masses above and below each mass for 230Th, 231Pa, and 233Pa. Tailing under each minor isotope was estimated as the log mean intensity of the half masses on either side of each minor isotope.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>2.2 Blank determinations</strong></p><p>In addition to laboratory procedural blanks (reagents/labware blanks) and periodic measurements of an intercalibrated working standard solution of 232Th, 230Th and 231Pa, SW STD 2010-1 referred to by Anderson et al. (2012), the participating labs also analyzed a number (n = 23) of "dipped blank" filters, mentioned above, to determine the total blank, associated with the sample collection and handling in addition to the laboratory procedure.&nbsp;</p><p>For better statistics, we pooled all procedural blank corrected "dipped" blanks (n = 23) to determine filter blank corrections. "Dipped" filter blanks for 232Th, 230Th, and 231Pa were from 156 ± 57 pg, 5.8 ± 2.0 fg, and 0.12 ± 0.04 fg, respectively. Total blanks were &lt; 10% of the measured isotope amounts, except shallower than 200 m water depth, where blanks could be on the order of 50% of the measured 230Th and 231Pa. &nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p>We define the limit of detection as 3 times the standard deviation in the measured "dipped" blanks (170 pg 232Th, 6.0 fg 230Th, and 0.13 fg 231Pa). There were 5 samples for which 231Pa was considered below detection, and all other samples were above the cited limits.</p><p>Further details on analysis of seawater particulate radionuclides are given by Anderson et al. (2012).&nbsp;</p>

gmd:credit.gmx:Anchor: Funding provided by NSF Ocean Sciences (NSF OCE) Award Number: OCE-0927064 Award URL: http://www.nsf.gov/awardsearch/showAward.do?AwardNumber=0927064

gmd:otherConstraints.gco:CharacterString: Access Constraints: none. Use Constraints: Please follow guidelines at: http://www.bco-dmo.org/terms-use Distribution liability: Under no circumstances shall BCO-DMO be liable for any direct, incidental, special, consequential, indirect, or punitive damages that result from the use of, or the inability to use, the materials in this data submission. If you are dissatisfied with any materials in this data submission your sole and exclusive remedy is to discontinue use.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: GEOTRACES is a SCOR sponsored program; and funding for program infrastructure development is provided by the U.S. National Science Foundation.GEOTRACES gained momentum following a special symposium, S02: Biogeochemical cycling of trace elements and isotopes in the ocean and applications to constrain contemporary marine processes (GEOSECS II), at a 2003 Goldschmidt meeting convened in Japan. The GEOSECS II acronym referred to the Geochemical Ocean Section Studies To determine full water column distributions of selected trace elements and isotopes, including their concentration, chemical speciation, and physical form, along a sufficient number of sections in each ocean basin to establish the principal relationships between these distributions and with more traditional hydrographic parameters;* To evaluate the sources, sinks, and internal cycling of these species and thereby characterize more completely the physical, chemical and biological processes regulating their distributions, and the sensitivity of these processes to global change; and* To understand the processes that control the concentrations of geochemical species used for proxies of the past environment, both in the water column and in the substrates that reflect the water column.GEOTRACES will be global in scope, consisting of ocean sections complemented by regional process studies. Sections and process studies will combine fieldwork, laboratory experiments and modelling. Beyond realizing the scientific objectives identified above, a natural outcome of this work will be to build a community of marine scientists who understand the processes regulating trace element cycles sufficiently well to exploit this knowledge reliably in future interdisciplinary studies.

gmd:otherCitationDetails.gco:CharacterString: http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32815.rdf Name: cruise_id Units: text Description: Official cruise identifier e.g. KN199-04 = R/V Knorr cruise number 199-04. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32816.rdf Name: cruise_part Units: text Description: identifier for a segment of a leg of a cruise, where a leg may have been broken into parts. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32817.rdf Name: station_GEOTRC Units: integer Description: GEOTRACES station number; ranges from 1 through 12 for KN199-04 and 1 through 24 for KN204-01. Stations 7 and 9 were skipped on KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'station', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32818.rdf Name: lat_sta Units: decimal degrees Description: nominal station latitude; north is positive http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32819.rdf Name: lon_sta Units: decimal degrees Description: nominal station longitude; east is positive http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32820.rdf Name: cast_GEOTRC Units: integer Description: Cast identifier numbered consecutively within a station. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'cast'; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32821.rdf Name: event_GEOTRC Units: dimensionless Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES sampling events; ranges from 2001 to 2225 for KN199-04 events and from 3001 to 3282 for KN204-01 events. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'event'; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32822.rdf Name: depth_GEOTRC_CTD Units: meters Description: Observation/sample depth in meters; calculated from CTD pressure. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'depth'; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32823.rdf Name: pump Units: dimensionless Description: McClane in-situ pump identifier http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32824.rdf Name: sample_GEOTRC Units: integer Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES samples; ranges from 5033 to 6078 for KN199-04 and from 6112 to 8148 for KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file Originally submitted as 'sample', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions. http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32825.rdf Name: Th232_susp Units: picograms 232Th per L seawater Description: suspended 232Th conc. (0.45-51 um) http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32826.rdf Name: Th232_susp_err Units: picograms 232Th per L seawater Description: 2 standard error uncertainty in 232Th_susp http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32827.rdf Name: Th232_susp_flag Units: 1 = good; 2 = questionable; 3 = bad Description: data quality flag for 232Th_susp http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32828.rdf Name: Th230_susp Units: femtograms 230Th per L seawater Description: suspended 230Th conc. (0.45-51 um) http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32829.rdf Name: Th230_susp_err Units: femtograms 230Th per L seawater Description: 2 standard error uncertainty in 230Th_susp http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32830.rdf Name: Th230_susp_flag Units: 1 = good; 2 = questionable; 3 = bad Description: data quality flag for 230Th_susp http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32831.rdf Name: Pa231_susp Units: femtograms 231Pa per L seawater Description: suspended 231Pa conc. (0.45-51 um) http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32832.rdf Name: Pa231_susp_err Units: femtograms 231Pa per L seawater Description: 2 standard error uncertainty in 231Pa_susp http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/32833.rdf Name: Pa231_susp_flag Units: 1 = good; 2 = questionable; 3 = bad Description: data quality flag for 231Pa_susp http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/33193.rdf Name: Sample_bottle_GEOTRC Units: dimensionless Description: Unique identification numbers given to samples taken from bottles; ranges from 1 to 24; often used synonymously with bottle number. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/33194.rdf Name: BTL_ISO_DateTime_UTC Units: YYYY-MM-DDTHH:MM:SS[.xx][+/-TZ] Description: Date and time (UTC) variable recorded at the bottle sampling time in ISO compliant format. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). This standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on the following form: 2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time) http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/521640.rdf Name: lab Units: unitless Description: location of analysis: WHOI = Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution; LDEO = Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory; UMinn = University of Minnesota http://lod.bco-dmo.org/id/dataset-parameter/521642.rdf Name: depth Units: meters Description: sample depth reported by PI

meridian of the point of interest. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P09/current/LONX/ Name: LONGITUDE Description: The angular distance east or west east or west of Greenwich to the point of interest. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P09/current/DEPH/ Name: DEPTH BELOW SEA SURFACE Description: The distance of a sensor or sampling point below the sea surface. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P02/current/ACYC/ Name: Reference numbers Description: Data record, event, sample or measurement reference numbers http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P03/current/C035/ Name: Metal and metalloid concentrations Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P01/current/T232STER/ Name: Activity standard error of thorium-232 {232Th} per unit dry weight of suspended particulate material by sediment trapping, digestion, purification, plating and alpha spectroscopy Description: Unavailable http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P03/current/C035/ Name: Metal and metalloid concentrations Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material. http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P01/current/ET30APXT/ Name: Activity standard error of thorium-230 {230Th} per unit dry weight of sediment by digestion, purification, plating and alpha spectroscopy Description: Alpha spectroscopy on plated purified digestion http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P02/current/ACYC/ Name: Reference numbers Description: Data record, event, sample or measurement reference numbers http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P01/current/DTUT8601/ Name: Date and time (UT in ISO8601 format to sub-second precision) Description: String corresponding to format 'yyyy-mm-ddThh:mi:ss.sss' optionally terminated by 'Z' http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/P09/current/DEPH/ Name: DEPTH BELOW SEA SURFACE Description: The distance of a sensor or sampling point below the sea surface.

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: Official cruise identifier e.g. KN199-04 = R/V Knorr cruise number 199-04.; General Description: cruise designation; name

PI-supplied Description: identifier for a segment of a leg of a cruise, where a leg may have been broken into parts.; General Description: Identifier for a segment of a leg of a cruise, where a leg may have been broken into parts.

PI-supplied Description: GEOTRACES station number; ranges from 1 through 12 for KN199-04 and 1 through 24 for KN204-01. Stations 7 and 9 were skipped on KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'station', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: consecutive station number

PI-supplied Description: nominal station latitude; north is positive; General Description: latitude, in decimal degrees, North is positive, negative denotes South; Reported in some datasets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance north or south from the equator, measured along the meridian of the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: nominal station longitude; east is positive; General Description: longitude, in decimal degrees, East is positive, negative denotes West; Reported in some datsets as degrees, minutes NERC Description: The angular distance east or west east or west of Greenwich to the point of interest.

PI-supplied Description: Cast identifier numbered consecutively within a station. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'cast'; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: cast or profile number

PI-supplied Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES sampling events; ranges from 2001 to 2225 for KN199-04 events and from 3001 to 3282 for KN204-01 events. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'event'; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: event or operation number; often derived from date/time (MMDDHHmm) of sampling and when combined with year (YYYY) is a unique sampling identifier/data processing key. Date/time is not necessarily in GMT.

PI-supplied Description: Observation/sample depth in meters; calculated from CTD pressure. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file. Originally submitted as 'depth'; this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: observation/sample depth, in meters; best estimate; usually but not always calculated from pressure; calculated either from CTD pressure using Fofonoff and Millard (1982; UNESCO Tech Paper #44) algorithm adjusted for 1980 equation of state for seawater (EOS80) or simply equivalent to nominal depth as recorded during sampling if CTD pressure was unavailable NERC Description: The distance of a sensor or sampling point below the sea surface.
PI-supplied Description: McClane in-situ pump identifier; General Description: association with a community-wide standard parameter is not yet defined

PI-supplied Description: Unique identifying number for US GEOTRACES samples; ranges from 5033 to 6078 for KN199-04 and from 6112 to 8148 for KN204-01. PI-supplied values were identical to those in the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file Originally submitted as 'sample', this parameter name has been changed to conform to BCO-DMO's GEOTRACES naming conventions.; General Description: unique sample identification or number; any combination of alpha numeric characters; precise definition is file dependent NERC Description: Data record, event, sample or measurement reference numbers

PI-supplied Description: suspended 232Th conc. (0.45-51 um); General Description: Concentration of a trace metal in seawater. Refer to dataset for element name and units. NERC Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material.

gco:attributeType.xlink:title: Activity standard error of thorium-232 {232Th} per unit dry weight of suspended particulate material by sediment trapping, digestion, purification, plating and alpha spectroscopy

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: 2 standard error uncertainty in 232Th_susp; General Description: thorium-232 error; file dependent; refer to data documentation for units and definition NERC Description: Unavailable

PI-supplied Description: data quality flag for 232Th_susp; General Description: Data flag. Multiple uses which are dataset dependent. Some uses: data quality, collection occurance or success, depth indicator. See dataset documentation for specific details

PI-supplied Description: suspended 230Th conc. (0.45-51 um); General Description: Concentration of a trace metal in seawater. Refer to dataset for element name and units. NERC Description: Parameters pertaining to metal and trace metalloid (i.e. excluding Si) concentrations in any material.

gco:attributeType.xlink:title: Activity standard error of thorium-230 {230Th} per unit dry weight of sediment by digestion, purification, plating and alpha spectroscopy

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: 2 standard error uncertainty in 230Th_susp; General Description: thorium-230 error; file dependent; refer to data documentation for units and definition NERC Description: Alpha spectroscopy on plated purified digestion

PI-supplied Description: data quality flag for 230Th_susp; General Description: Data flag. Multiple uses which are dataset dependent. Some uses: data quality, collection occurance or success, depth indicator. See dataset documentation for specific details
PI-supplied Description: suspended 231Pa conc. (0.45-51 um); General Description: protactinium-231; in sediments
PI-supplied Description: 2 standard error uncertainty in 231Pa_susp; General Description: protactinium-231 error; file dependent; refer to data documentation for units and definition

PI-supplied Description: data quality flag for 231Pa_susp; General Description: Data flag. Multiple uses which are dataset dependent. Some uses: data quality, collection occurance or success, depth indicator. See dataset documentation for specific details

PI-supplied Description: Unique identification numbers given to samples taken from bottles; ranges from 1 to 24; often used synonymously with bottle number. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description).; General Description: unique sample identification or number; any combination of alpha numeric characters; precise definition is file dependent NERC Description: Data record, event, sample or measurement reference numbers

gco:attributeType.xlink:title: Date and time (UT in ISO8601 format to sub-second precision)

gmd:descriptor.gco:CharacterString: PI-supplied Description: Date and time (UTC) variable recorded at the bottle sampling time in ISO compliant format. Values were added from the intermediate US GEOTRACES master file (see Processing Description). This standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on the following form: 2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time); General Description: Date/Time (UTC) ISO formattedThis standard is based on ISO 8601:2004(E) and takes on any of the following forms:2009-08-30T09:05:00[.xx] (local time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]-05:00The dashes and the colons can be dropped.The T can also be dropped "by mutual agreement", but one needs the trailing Z if the time is UTC.Sample ISO_datetime_utc:2009-08-30T14:05:00[.xx]Z (UTC time)Format: YYYY-mm-ddTHH:MM:SS[.xx]Z (UTC time) NERC Description: String corresponding to format 'yyyy-mm-ddThh:mi:ss.sss' optionally terminated by 'Z'

PI-supplied Description: location of analysis: WHOI = Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution; LDEO = Lamont Doherty Earth Observatory; UMinn = University of Minnesota; General Description: Laboratory Id – Lab identifier where experiments were conducted

PI-supplied Description: sample depth reported by PI; General Description: observation/sample depth, in meters; best estimate; usually but not always calculated from pressure; calculated either from CTD pressure using Fofonoff and Millard (1982; UNESCO Tech Paper #44) algorithm adjusted for 1980 equation of state for seawater (EOS80) or simply equivalent to nominal depth as recorded during sampling if CTD pressure was unavailable NERC Description: The distance of a sensor or sampling point below the sea surface.

gmd:description.gco:CharacterString: <p><strong>Sampling and Analytical Methodology: &nbsp;<br />1. Sampling:</strong><br />Size-fractionated particles were collected using McLane Research in-situ pumps (WTS-LV) that had been modified to accommodate two flowpaths (Lam and Morris Patent pending). &nbsp; The wire-out was used to target depths during deployment, and a self-recording Seabird 19plus CTD deployed at the end of the line and RBR data loggers attached to three of the eight pumps were used to correct for actual depths during pumping.</p><p>Filter holders used were 142 mm-diameter "mini-MULVFS" style filter holders with two stages for two size fractions and multiple baffle systems designed to ensure even particle distribution and prevent particle loss (Bishop et al. 2012). &nbsp;One of two filter holder/flowpaths was loaded with a 51µm Sefar polyester mesh prefilter followed by paired 0.8 µm Pall Supor800 polyethersulfone filters. &nbsp;Each cast also had "dipped blank" filters deployed. &nbsp;These were the full filters sets (prefilter followed by paired Supor filters) sandwiched within a 1 µm polyester mesh filter, loaded into perforated polypropylene containers, attached with plastic cable ties to a pump frame, and deployed. &nbsp;Dipped blank filters were exposed to seawater for the length of the deployment and processed and analyzed as regular samples, and thus functioned as full seawater process blanks. &nbsp;We analyzed half portions of the top and bottom filters from the "dipped" blank from 1 or more depths for 7 stations.</p><p>All filters and filter holders were acid leached prior to use according to methods recommended in the GEOTRACES sample and sample-handing Protocols (Geotraces 2010).</p><p><strong>2. Analysis:</strong><br />The Supor filters were subsampled in an on-shore laboratory at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution and shipped to the participating labs for Pa/Th analysis. Twenty-five to 50% of the paired Supor filters, representing 55-350 L of seawater, were used for Pa/Th analysis. Analyses were similar but differed slightly for the Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory, WHOI and the University of Minnesota. Details of each groups methodologies can be found in reports by Anderson et al. (2012), Auro et al. (2012) and Shen et al. (2002, 2003, 2012), respectively. Below we give a typical procedure used at L-DEO for illustrative purposes.<br />&nbsp;<br /><strong>2.1 L-DEO procedures</strong><br />&nbsp;&nbsp;<br />Filters were folded into 60 mL Teflon jars and weighed aliquots of the artificial isotope yield monitors 229Th (1 pg) and 233Pa (0.3-0.4 pg) and 7-8 mg dissolved Fe were added to each sample. Filters were first heated in ~5 mL 8 N HNO3 for 1-2 hours at 150°C, then 4-5 mL HClO4 was added and heat was increased to 200°C until dense white fumes appeared for ~10-20 min. The heat was then reduced to 180°C and the samples were covered with a Teflon watch cover. After 1-4 hrs, oxidation of the Supor material accelerated, sometimes producing a foam. A foamed sample would be allowed to cool, and re-heated after the beaker walls and watch cover were washed with small amounts of HNO3 or Milli-Q water. When the Supor material was largely broken down, the watch covers were removed and HF was added in 2 aliquots of ~10-15 drops in between reheating until attaining dense HClO4 fumes for at least 10 min.</p><p>After total dissolution of the sample, the sample-HClO4 residue was taken up in dilute HCl, and transferred to 50 mL centrifuge tubes with water rinses. Ten to 20 drops of NH4OH were added to raise pH to 8-8.5 when iron (oxy)hydroxide precipitated. This precipitate was then centrifuged, decanted, washed with Milli-Q H2O, centrifuged, and dissolved in 12 M HCl for a series of anion-exchange chromatography using 6 mL polypropylene columns each containing a 1 mL bed of Bio-rad resin (AG1-X8, 100-200 mesh size) and a 45 µm porous polyethylene frit (Anderson et al. 2012). The final column elutions were dried down at 180°C in the presence of 2 drops of HClO4 and taken up in approximately 1 mL of 0.16 M HNO3/0.026 M HF for mass spectrometric analysis. All acids and bases used were Fisher Chemical OPTIMA grade.&nbsp;<br />&nbsp;<br />Concentrations of 232Th, 230Th and 231Pa were calculated by isotope dilution using nuclide ratios determined on a Thermo Scientific Element XR Inductively-couple plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) in low resolution. All measurements were done using a peak jumping routine in ion counting mode. A solution of SRM129, a natural U standard, was run to determine the mass bias correction (assuming that the mass fractionation for Th and Pa are the same as for U). Each sample measurement was bracketed by measurement of an aliquot of the run solution, used to correct for the instrument background count rates on the masses measured. To correct for potential tailing of 232Th into the minor Th and Pa isotopes, beam intensities were measured at the half masses above and below each mass for 230Th, 231Pa, and 233Pa. Tailing under each minor isotope was estimated as the log mean intensity of the half masses on either side of each minor isotope.&nbsp;</p><p><strong>2.2 Blank determinations</strong></p><p>In addition to laboratory procedural blanks (reagents/labware blanks) and periodic measurements of an intercalibrated working standard solution of 232Th, 230Th and 231Pa, SW STD 2010-1 referred to by Anderson et al. (2012), the participating labs also analyzed a number (n = 23) of "dipped blank" filters, mentioned above, to determine the total blank, associated with the sample collection and handling in addition to the laboratory procedure.&nbsp;</p><p>For better statistics, we pooled all procedural blank corrected "dipped" blanks (n = 23) to determine filter blank corrections. "Dipped" filter blanks for 232Th, 230Th, and 231Pa were from 156 ± 57 pg, 5.8 ± 2.0 fg, and 0.12 ± 0.04 fg, respectively. Total blanks were &lt; 10% of the measured isotope amounts, except shallower than 200 m water depth, where blanks could be on the order of 50% of the measured 230Th and 231Pa. &nbsp; &nbsp;</p><p>We define the limit of detection as 3 times the standard deviation in the measured "dipped" blanks (170 pg 232Th, 6.0 fg 230Th, and 0.13 fg 231Pa). There were 5 samples for which 231Pa was considered below detection, and all other samples were above the cited limits.</p><p>Further details on analysis of seawater particulate radionuclides are given by Anderson et al. (2012).&nbsp;</p>

<p><strong>Data Processing: </strong><br />The reported errors for radionuclide concentrations represent the propagation of 2 standard errors, based on the standard deviation of the average isotope ratios collected by ICP-MS, estimated error in the 229Th or 233Pa spike concentration, and the total blank correction.</p><p><strong>Related files and references:</strong>&nbsp;<br />Anderson, R.F., Fleisher, M.Q., Robinson, L.F., Edwards, R.L., Hoff, J., Moran, S.B., Rutgers van der Loeff, M.M., Thomas, A.L., Roy-Barman, M., François, R., 2012. GEOTRACES intercalibration of 230Th, 232Th, 231Pa, and prospects for 10Be. Limnol. Oceanogr. Methods 10, 179-213.<br /><br />Auro, M.E., Robinson, L.F., Burke, A., Bradtmiller, L.I., Fleisher, M.Q., Anderson, R.F., 2012. Improvements to 232-thorium, 230-thorium, and 231-protactinium analysis in seawater arising from GEOTRACES intercalibration. Limnol. Oceanogr. Methods 10, 464-474.</p><p>Bishop, J. K. B., P. J. Lam, and T. J. Wood. 2012. Getting good particles: accurate sampling of particles by large volume in-situ filtration. Limnology and Oceanography Methods 10: 681-710.<br /><br />Lam, P. J., and P. J. Morris. Patent pending. In situ marine sample collection system and methods, Goodwin Docket No. WHOI-005PR.<br /><br />Geotraces. 2010. Sample and sample-handing protocols for GEOTRACES Cruises. In Standards and Intercalibration Committee [ed.]. <a href="http://www.geotraces.org/libraries/documents/Intercalibration/Cookbook.pdf" target="_blank">http://www.geotraces.org/libraries/documents/Intercalibration/Cookbook.pdf</a><br />&nbsp;</p><p><strong>Additional GEOTRACES Processing Performed by BCO-DMO:</strong>&nbsp; After the data were submitted to the International Data Management Office, BODC, the office noticed that important identifying information was missing in many datasets. With the agreement of BODC and the US GEOTRACES lead PIs, BCO-DMO added standard US GEOTRACES information, such as the US GEOTRACES event number, to each submitted dataset lacking this information. To accomplish this, BCO-DMO compiled a 'master' dataset composed of the following parameters: station_GEOTRC, cast_GEOTRC (bottle and pump data only), event_GEOTRC, sample_GEOTRC, sample_bottle_GEOTRC (bottle data only), bottle_GEOTRC (bottle data only), depth_GEOTRC_CTD (bottle data only), depth_GEOTRC_CTD_rounded (bottle data only), BTL_ISO_DateTime_UTC (bottle data only), and GeoFish_id (GeoFish data only). This added information will facilitate subsequent analysis and inter comparison of the datasets.</p><p>Bottle parameters in the master file were taken from the GT-C_Bottle_GT10, GT-C_Bottle_GT11, ODF_Bottle_GT10, and ODF_Bottle_GT11 datasets. Non-bottle parameters, including those from GeoFish tows, Aerosol sampling, and McLane Pumps, were taken from the Event_Log_GT10 and Event_Log_GT11 datasets. McLane pump cast numbers missing in event logs were taken from the Particulate Th-234 dataset submitted by Ken Buesseler.</p><p>A standardized BCO-DMO method (called “join”) was then used to merge the missing parameters to each US GEOTRACES dataset, most often by matching on sample_GEOTRC or on some unique combination of other parameters.</p><p>If the master parameters were included in the original data file and the values did not differ from the master file, the original data columns were retained and the name of the parameters were changed from the PI-submitted names to the standardized master names. If there were differences between the PI-supplied parameter values and those in the master file, both columns were retained. If the original data submission included all of the master parameters, no additional columns were added, but parameter names were modified to match the naming conventions of the master file.</p><p>See the dataset parameters documentation for a description of which parameters were supplied by the PI and which were added via the join method.</p>

gmd:organisationName.gmx:Anchor: Biological and Chemical Oceanography Data Management Office (BCO-DMO)

gmd:contactInstructions.gco:CharacterString: For questions regarding this resource, please contact BCO-DMO via the email address provided.

gmi:description.gco:CharacterString: PI Supplied Instrument Name: McLane Pump PI Supplied Instrument Description:McLane Research in-situ pumps (WTS-LV) that had been modified to accommodate two flowpaths (Lam and Morris Patent pending). The wire-out was used to target depths during deployment, and a self-recording Seabird 19plus CTD deployed at the end of the line and RBR data loggers attached to three of the eight pumps were used to correct for actual depths during pumping.Samples were collected with the pump over paired 0.8um Pall Supor800 polyethersulfone filters behind a 51 um Sefar polyester mesh prefilter (See sampling Methodology for details).142 mm-diameter "mini-MULVFS" style filter holders with two stages for two size fractions and multiple baffle systems designed to ensure even particle distribution and prevent particle loss (Bishop et al. 2012). One of two filter holder/flowpaths was loaded with a 51µm Sefar polyester mesh prefilter followed by paired 0.8 µm Pall Supor800 polyethersulfone filters. Instrument Name: McLane Pump Instrument Short Name:McLane Pump Instrument Description: McLane pumps sample large volumes of seawater at depth. They are attached to a wire and lowered to different depths in the ocean. As the water is pumped through the filter, particles suspended in the ocean are collected on the filters. The pumps are then retrieved and the contents of the filters are analyzed in a lab.

PI Supplied Instrument Name: Mass Spectrometer PI Supplied Instrument Description:Thermo Scientific Element XR Inductively-couple plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS) Instrument Name: Mass Spectrometer Instrument Short Name:Mass Spec Instrument Description: General term for instruments used to measure the mass-to-charge ratio of ions; generally used to find the composition of a sample by generating a mass spectrum representing the masses of sample components. Community Standard Description: http://vocab.nerc.ac.uk/collection/L05/current/LAB16/

gmd:title.gmx:Anchor: International Council for the Exploration of the Sea
International Council for the Exploration of the Sea
